title: Center of Attention: How Facebook Users Allocate Attention across Friends
segmentation: OK, so I'm going to talk about some work that I did with Lars Backstrom, Jon Kleinberg, Tomlin to Anne Itamar, Rosenn on how users distribute their attack.
And across friends, some first going to motivate the work very briefly and then talk about the data and what exactly we're measuring.
And then we're going to propose this measurement, called the balance of attention.
And relate it to key variables like how much users interact with other users on Facebook according to a certain modality.
How many people they interact with and then talk about individual variation.
Because this balance of attention turns turns out to be a relatively stable property of the individual overtime.
And then I'm going to talk about intergroup variation, so specifically gender so males and females interact with each other and allocate their attention differently.
And then I'll talk briefly about temporal shifts and variations.
So how stable are your top friends?
So do these core friendships persist overtime?
And then I'll.
Conclude so.
Motivation?
So.
Or what we're interested in is.
As more and more activity moves online.
This this new medium is augmenting how many people we can interact with and how we can divide our attention amongst our friends.
It's not just the people that we live with, but it could be spatially extended and it's not really clear how that affects our core group of friends or the people that we interact with most often.
And this is a little kind of similar to some early work that was raised by Stanley Milgrom on the urban experience.
So what he noted is that there's this transition from living in like a regular sized village or suburb to Midtown Manhattan.
You could reach about two orders of magnitude more people within walking distance, and this is kind of similar in the online domain.
We can just with a few button clicks, have access to hundreds of thousands of people's Twitter feeds, for example.

Make you in levenger.

Overall affect some core group of your.
Friends.

So our claim is that attention is allocated differently across your friends and that increased activity or network size does not necessarily mean that you're spending less time with your core friends.
So to do this, we measure the percentage of your attention according to different modalities of communication observation.
That goes to your top set of friends.

But we choose this number kind of appropriately to eliminate some confounding factors.
An analysis like this were not really previously possible, right?
'cause to measure this percentage?
You need complete information about how you're interacting with everybody, right?

And we can compare across different modalities.
